thread.title: Celtics Notes: Rozier relegated to sideline with bruised knee
thread.title_full: Celtics Notes: Rozier relegated to sideline with bruised knee | Boston Herald

author: Mark Murphy
title: Celtics Notes: Rozier relegated to sideline with bruised knee
text:
Terry Rozier , one of the quickest rookies the Celtics have ever brought into camp, has to learn how to slow down this week.
The point guard, suffering from a bruised left knee during last Thursday’s win over Real Madrid, said he will be sidelined the rest of the week, indicating he will not play during the Celtics’ two-game exhibition swing through New York this week against the Nets and Knicks.
“Just a bone bruise, that’s it, nothing serious, swelling,” Rozier said before today’s practice. “I’m out for a couple of days, but I’m in the pool doing pool work, I’m on the bike, just slowly working back into it. I’m not playing for the rest of this week.”
Rozier, whose left knee was heavily taped, was playing well prior to the injury. Naturally, he didn’t want something like a knee-to-knee collision to get in the way of his second exhibition game.
“I thought I could just get through it, but lesson learned from that,” he said.
But now is not the time to push a player through unnecessary strain, according to Brad Stevens .
“The goal is to be healthy and ready to roll on Oct. 28,” said the Celtics coach.
Jones in mourning
When Perry Jones received news that a close cousin had died back in Texas while the Celtics were touring Europe, Stevens didn’t bother to debate the issue, or discuss whether it was advisable for Jones to go see his family.
“I told him (to go),” said the Celtics coach.
Jones had returned to the team by yesterday’s practice, trying hard to conceal his grief.
“I can’t talk about it right now. I’d get too emotional,” he said. “I spent time with family. It’s a tough time, just a few days to spend with the family was important to me. From a mental standpoint it was a good thing I went, preparing for what will happen in the future.”
Jones, who only played seven minutes on the trip — a two-point, two-rebound performance against Olimpia Milan — is in a fight to make the roster. He has some lost time to make up.
“There’s a few things I have to catch up on, but that will be easy with my teammates helping me,” he said. . . .
Jonas Jerebko (illness) returned to practice yesterday. Evan Turner , still suffering from a strained right knee that forced him to miss both games in Europe, was again a spectator at yesterday’s practice.
